comment._content:
How does one dismount from a penny-farthing bicycle?!!
Stuart.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 99646216@N00
comment._content: My grandfather (b. 1873) once rode on a penny farthing when he was a youngster - he dismounted head first, at speed. He was still laughing about it aged 92.

comment.author: 30484128@N03
comment._content: They do look difficult to ride.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: So no harm done to his sense of humour then, hockadilly!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: Based on his leggings and cap, I'd be pretty sure the bike is his...

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content:
This is more correctly called an'Ordinary' and this appears to be the club model introduced by Coventry Machinists Company Limited in 1878. This was the classic touring bicycle. This looks as if it might be the full 56 inch model which was introduced about 1885.

When I get a chance I'll do a search in the volumes of The Irish Cyclist in the RIAC Archive and see if I can confirm any details about the rider.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Thanks, Bob! Whenever you can check, it'd be much appreciated, and then I can amend the date on this one if you're right...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
